title: Learning Objectives
text:
Part 1 Learning Objectives Brain Dump



Discover useful APIs
Process web data into R-standard formats
Fetch data with simple APIs
Fetch lots of data from APIs
Authenticate with APIs
Find specific APIs



Do other things (send/update/delete data) with APIs
Find R packages that wrap APIs
(Use other forms of APIs?)
Get web data without APIs ({rvest})
Learn more about accessing APIs





Discover: Just vaguely via apis.guru or similar.
Process: This isn‚Äôt API-specific, but APIs often have deeply nested data
Fetch data: No auth. Very basic parsing of the return
Fetch lots: Important concept regardless of whether it‚Äôs ‚Äúsimple‚Äù
Authenticate: Complicated (see Slack), I want to make it as clear as possible

In part 2 we‚Äôll build the complicated thing, I think.

Find specific: Shoved this way down the list because it will be hard to have examples that aren‚Äôt easy. I think I‚Äôll replace apis.guru with a true wiki.
Do other: curl_translate() deep dive here.
Find R packages: I want it late so you can tell if it‚Äôs a bad package
Others: gRPC, GraphQL, Websockets
rvest: Technically could skip?
Learn more: Book recommendations, blogs, etc.

title: How can I access APIs from R?
text:
What do {httr2} calls look like?

Pipe-based API calls



candidates <- 
  request("https://api.open.fec.gov/v1") |> 
  req_url_path_append("candidates") |> 
  req_url_query(api_key = "DEMO_KEY") |> 
  req_url_query(election_year = 2024) |> 
  req_perform() |> 
  resp_body_json()
candidates$results[[1]]$candidate_id
#> [1] "P40014052"




httr2 is a rewrite of httr specifically to use the concept of the pipe.

I‚Äôll add a brief intro to the pipe in the Introduction chapter under prereqs!
I use |> base R pipe here. Pronounce it ‚Äúand then‚Äù.

httr2 calls usually involve a request, which you perform, and then you parse the response.
We‚Äôre hitting the free, open api from the Federal Elections Commission.

I‚Äôm thinking about building a Shiny app related to this API, and using it as a case study throughout the book, but I also need to find stable APIs with more options
Stable API ideas? Ideally free. I also might host something for people to use.

(step through)
Here we build the request piece-wise

We‚Äôll get into details of the functions in a few slides

Then we perform the request. This actually hits the server.
Then we parse what we get back with a resp_body function.
This returns a larger object in a format called JSON, will talk about it more in a later chapter

title: How can I access APIs from R?
text:
Why ‚Äúhttr‚Äù?

HTTP = HyperText Transfer Protocol

‚ÄúHyperText‚Äù = web content
‚ÄúTransfer‚Äù = exchange
‚ÄúProtocol‚Äù = rules
‚Äúrules for exchanging web content‚Äù
HTTP(S) = most of internet communication




You may have seen http or https at the start of URLs (web addresses)
‚Äúweb content‚Äù =

originally text and links (HTML = HyperText Markup Language)
now data, images, videos, etc.

‚Äúexchange‚Äù or ‚Äúmove‚Äù
‚ÄúS‚Äù means ‚Äúsecure‚Äù
If anyone asks: 1.1 = most, 2.0 = 2-way

‚ÄúHTTP in R, take 2‚Äù

title: How can I access APIs from R?
text:
How do I use {httr2}?

req_*() functions return httr2_request objects



req_fec <- request("https://api.open.fec.gov/v1")
req_fec_auth <- req_url_query(req_fec, api_key = "DEMO_KEY")
req_candidates <- req_url_path_append(req_fec_auth, "candidates")
candidates_2024 <- req_url_query(req_candidates, election_year = 2024) |> 
  req_perform() |> resp_body_json()
candidates_2022 <- req_url_query(req_candidates, election_year = 2022) |> 
  req_perform() |> resp_body_json()
req_calendar <- req_url_path_append(req_fec_auth, "calendar-dates")




Imagine you‚Äôre working with an API, like the FEC API

What you‚Äôll very often do.

We‚Äôll go through function specifics in a moment, just soak in the utility of separate objects
This is super important, so let‚Äôs pause to sink this in
I‚Äôm going to drink some water while you make sure you have that.

title: How can I access APIs from R?
section: How can I quickly translate API docs?
text:
How can I quickly translate API docs?

Docs often have ‚ÄúTry it out‚Äù option

https://api.open.fec.gov/developers/

Copy the ‚ÄúCurl‚Äù block



curl_translate(
  "curl -X 'GET' \
  'https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates/?api_key=DEMO_KEY&office=H'"
)



request("https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates/") |> 
  req_method("GET") |> 
  req_url_query(
    api_key = "DEMO_KEY",
    office = "H"
  ) |> 
  req_perform()



If you want to use this API, sign up for your own key at that same URL.
I edited the given curl to fit
This code will usually get you started
Now let‚Äôs clean it up and understand it!
Extra: OpenAPI 3.0 description at https://api.apis.guru/v2/specs/fec.gov/1.0/openapi.json
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How can I access APIs from R?

title: How can I access APIs from R?
text:
request() & req_path_append()

request("https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates/") |> 
  req_method("GET") |> 
  req_url_query(
    api_key = "DEMO_KEY",
    office = "H"
  ) |> 
  req_perform()


Cleaner: ‚Äúmain‚Äù request object + specific path

req_fec <- request("https://api.open.fec.gov/v1")
req_candidates <- req_fec |> 
  req_url_path_append("candidates")




req_candidates$url

#> [1] "https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates"





httr2 ‚Äúthinks‚Äù in pieces
You don‚Äôt have to think about the /
We have to be careful about the ‚Äúv1‚Äù in our request, though!

More on next slide.
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How can I access APIs from R?

title: How can I access APIs from R?
text:
Don‚Äôt use req_url_path()!


req_path_bad <- req_fec |> 
  req_url_path("candidates")
req_path_bad$url

#> [1] "https://api.open.fec.gov/candidates"





req_candidates$url

#> [1] "https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates"





You probably never want req_url_path()
Notably the help docs don‚Äôt show an example for this one

title: How can I access APIs from R?
text:
req_url_query()

https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates/?api_key=DEMO_KEY&office=H



req_house <- req_candidates |> 
  req_url_query(
    api_key = "DEMO_KEY",
    office = "H"
  )



Can add query parameters piecewise, even before path!



req_fec_auth <- req_fec |> 
  req_url_query(api_key = "DEMO_KEY")
req_candidates_auth <- req_fec_auth |> 
  req_url_path_append("candidates")
req_house2 <- req_candidates_auth |> 
  req_url_query(office = "H")




identical(req_house$url, req_house2$url)

#> [1] TRUE





This is the URL that was in the Curl call
‚ÄúQuery‚Äù = stuff after ‚Äú?‚Äù
Arguments for the endpoint
1st req_url_query() call is what curl_translate gave us
Doesn‚Äôt automatically set order, so watch out for that.
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How can I access APIs from R?

title: How can I access APIs from R?
text:
req_url_query(.multi)


req_url_query(req_candidates, office = c("H", "S"))

#> Error in `req_url_query()`:
#> ! All vector elements of `...` must be length 1.
#> ‚Ñπ Use `.multi` to choose a strategy for handling vectors.




.multi = "pipe"

req_url_query(req_candidates, office = c("H", "S"), .multi = "pipe")$url

#> [1] "https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates?office=H|S"




.multi = "comma"

req_url_query(req_candidates, office = c("H", "S"), .multi = "comma")$url

#> [1] "https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates?office=H,S"




.multi = "explode"

req_url_query(req_candidates, office = c("H", "S"), .multi = "explode")$url

#> [1] "https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/candidates?office=H&office=S"





APIs often can‚Äôt handle multiple params with same name
default = ‚Äúerror‚Äù
. in .multi so it doesn‚Äôt collide with a parameter named ‚Äúmulti‚Äù
‚Äúpipe‚Äù or ‚Äúcomma‚Äù to list them out in same parameter
‚Äúexplode‚Äù to separate them as separate copies of that parameter (what this API actually wants)

text:
API Descriptions

APIs.guru
OpenFEC
YouTube Data API v3
Asana



Technically the OpenAPI specification is the standard, and each API has a ‚Äúdescription‚Äù
OpenAPI 3.0+ easier to use than Swagger (aka 2.0)
Still some confusing bits, such as security vs components$securitySchemas
People can and will do things wrong/weird.

title: How can I use an API description?
text:

youtube_spec <- yaml::read_yaml("https://api.apis.guru/v2/specs/googleapis.com/youtube/v3/openapi.yaml")




names(youtube_spec)

#> [1] "openapi"      "servers"      "info"         "externalDocs" "tags"        
#> [6] "paths"        "components"

title: How can I use an API description?
How can I use an API description?
How can I use an API description?
text:
Path details

youtube_paths |> tidyr::unnest(operations) |> dplyr::glimpse()

#> Rows: 76
#> Columns: 11
#> $ endpoint          <chr> "/youtube/v3/abuseReports", "/youtube/v3/activities"‚Ä¶
#> $ operation         <chr> "post", "get", "delete", "get", "post", "put", "get"‚Ä¶
#> $ summary           <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, ‚Ä¶
#> $ description       <chr> "Inserts a new resource into this collection.", "Ret‚Ä¶
#> $ operation_id      <chr> "youtube.abuseReports.insert", "youtube.activities.l‚Ä¶
#> $ tags              <chr> "abuseReports", "activities", "captions", "captions"‚Ä¶
#> $ parameters        <list> [<tbl_df[1 x 9]>], [<tbl_df[9 x 9]>], [<tbl_df[3 x ‚Ä¶
#> $ request_body      <list> [<tbl_df[1 x 3]>], <NULL>, <NULL>, <NULL>, [<tbl_df‚Ä¶
#> $ responses         <list> [<tbl_df[1 x 5]>], [<tbl_df[1 x 5]>], [<tbl_df[1 x ‚Ä¶
#> $ deprecated        <lgl> FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FAL‚Ä¶
#> $ global_parameters <list> [<tbl_df[11 x 9]>], [<tbl_df[11 x 9]>], [<tbl_df[11‚Ä¶




(endpoint = path)
(operation = method = more details in a few chapters)
summary is meant for a very brief description, not often used
description can have markdown
operation_id = unique string for this operation, meant for tools to use as a function name
tags = Categories; can have more than one per endpoint, but often just one
parameters = tibble of inputs
request_body = tibble of a fancier type of input (later chapter)
responses = tibble of expected output
deprecated = is this endpoint no longer intended to be used
global_parameters = tibble of shared inputs
This tibble contains MOST of the useful information about the API

We‚Äôll dig into this tibble for a simple API in the next chapter

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
JSON

application/json or */json
4 scalars (length-1 vectors)

null ‚âà NA
string ‚âà character(1), always " (not ')
number ‚âà numeric(1), no Inf/-Inf/NaN
boolean ‚âà logical(1), true = TRUE, false = FALSE

array ‚âà unnamed list()

[]: [null, "a", 1, true] ‚âà list(NULL, "a", 1, TRUE)

object ‚âà named list()

{}: {"a": 1, "b": [1, 2]} ‚âà list(a = 1, b = list(1, 2))

httr2::resp_body_json() uses jsonlite::fromJSON()

Can I legally scrape this data?

Personal use or nonprofit education = usually ok
Be careful about personally identifiable information (PII)
Check legal disclaimers (but may be over-protective)
US:

Can‚Äôt copyright facts,
CAN copyright collections of facts in some cases (creative)

Other places:

Sometimes stricter (EU)
Sometimes more lax

#> [3] "1password.local:connect"       "6-dot-authentiqio.appspot.com"
#> [5] "ably.io:platform"              "ably.net:control"





purrr::pluck_depth(all_apis)

#> [1] 10





str(head(all_apis, 2), max.level = 2)

#> List of 2
#>  $ 1forge.com          :List of 3
#>   ..$ added    : chr "2017-05-30T08:34:14.000Z"
#>   ..$ preferred: chr "0.0.1"
#>   ..$ versions :List of 1
#>  $ 1password.com:events:List of 3
#>   ..$ added    : chr "2021-07-19T10:17:09.188Z"
#>   ..$ preferred: chr "1.0.0"
#>   ..$ versions :List of 1





jsonlite = one of several packages for parsing JSON

We‚Äôll stick with it because it works & is used by higher-level packages
Used in {shiny}, {httr}, {httr2}, dozens of other packages

fromJSON does some automatic guessing, we‚Äôll come back to this in a later chapter

Alternatives: read_json reads file, parse_json reads string; don‚Äôt guess by default

This result is a huge, nested list
purrr::pluck_depth() tells you how nested a list is
hard to see this. Let‚Äôs rectangle it!
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How can I get started with APIs?

title: How can I get started with APIs?
text:
Unnesting

Is value a list of lists of observations?

tidyr::unnest_longer(value) separates into rows

Is value a list of lists of variables?

tidyr::unnest_wider(value) separates into columns

tidyr::unnest_auto() uses heuristic to choose between those



Tidy data: Every row is a single observation, every column is a single variable.
‚ÄúHeuristic‚Äù is a fancy word for ‚Äúset of rules.‚Äù I used it here specifically so I can define it and try to demystify it.
unnest_auto() isn‚Äôt perfect.
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How can I get started with APIs?

title: How can I get started with APIs?
section: How does unnest_auto() choose unnest direction?
text:
How does unnest_auto() choose unnest direction?


element_names <- purrr::map(df$col, names)
has_null <- unique(purrr::map_lgl(element_names, is.null))
identical(has_null, TRUE)?

unnest_longer(col, indices_include = FALSE)

identical(has_null, FALSE)?

common_names <- purrr::reduce(element_names, intersect)
length(common_names) > 0?

unnest_wider(col)

length(common_names) == 0?

unnest_longer(col, indices_include = TRUE)


Leftovers: unnest_longer(col, indices_include = FALSE)




This will be a flowchart.
Get the names of the elements of the column. We‚Äôll use this info for the rest of our decisions.
Check whether any elements lack names

All lack names? Unnest longer.
All have names? Check for shared names

Shared names? Unnest wider.
No shared names? Unnest longer, include indices.

Mix of named and unnamd? Unnest longer, drop indices.

title: How can I get started with APIs?
text:
What does unnest_auto() miss? (1)
Column is a named list (not a list of named lists).

Error: Names are lost
Check: rlang::is_named(df$col)
Fix: dplyr::mutate(col_name = names(col)) before unnesting.
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How can I get started with APIs?

title: How can I get started with APIs?
text:
What does unnest_auto() miss? (2)
One or more elements of a list column are empty.

Error: Assumes unnest_longer(), even if it‚Äôs just some missing values among a column that is obviously otherwise unnest_wider-worthy.
Check: any(lengths(df$col) == 0)
Fix: Do the unnest_auto() checks only on values of col that have lengths(col) > 0


An empty item doesn‚Äôt have any names.
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How can I get started with APIs?

title: How can I get started with APIs?
text:
What does unnest_auto() miss? (3)
One or more elements of a list column lacks names, other elements have names.

Error: Names are lost.
Check: (flowchart already tests this, but makes the wrong decision)
Fix: unnest_longer(col, indices_to = "descriptive_name") as fall-through

section: How should I choose unnest direction?
text:
How should I choose unnest direction?


rlang::is_named(df$col)?

dplyr::mutate(names_col = names(col), .before = col)

non_empties <- df$col[lengths(df$col) > 0]

element_names <- purrr::map(df$col, names)

has_null <- unique(purrr::map_lgl(element_names, is.null))
identical(has_null, TRUE)?

unnest_longer(col, indices_include = FALSE)

identical(has_null, FALSE)?

common_names <- purrr::reduce(element_names, intersect)
length(common_names) > 0?

unnest_wider(col)

length(common_names) == 0?

unnest_longer(col, indices_include = TRUE)


Leftovers: unnest_longer(col, indices_to = "descriptive_name")




Does the overall column have names? Avoid losing the names
Get the names of the non-empty elements of the column. We‚Äôll use this for the rest of our decisions.
(no change)
(no change)
(no change, but see validation)

(no change)

Validate this! Overlapping names could be coincidental (eg, first version is always ‚Äúv1‚Äù, some have additional versions)


Leftovers: Mix of named and unnamed elements, or no shared names.

Keep the names when they exist!

text:
value column: Unnest wider or longer?
(incorporate flowchart once it exists)


rlang::is_named(all_apis_df$value)

#> [1] FALSE





non_empties <- all_apis_df$value[lengths(all_apis_df$value) > 0]
element_names <- purrr::map(non_empties, names)

has_null

#> [1] FALSE





common_names <- purrr::reduce(element_names, intersect)




common_names

#> [1] "added"     "preferred" "versions"





Wider if multiple variables per value, longer if multiple observations per value.
The purrr reduce thing checks for names that everything shares (inspired by unnest_auto).
(make sure everyone groks why wider)

swaggerUrl is JSON, swaggerYamlUrl is YAML version of the same thing
YAML is another data format. Technically YAML is a superset of JSON, with added commenting capabilities.
RMarkdown headers + package descriptions are YAML-related.
We‚Äôll see more about YAML and find out what ‚ÄúSwagger‚Äù means in the next chapter!

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
Error responses
API errors are still responses

Status code specifies broad error category (see next slide)

400 to 499 = Client errors (user did something wrong)
500 to 599 = Server errors (something is broken)
Reminder: By default, {plumber} uses 500

Best practice: Error format same as successful response

Be careful about this, don‚Äôt make silent errors easy!

Need plumber::pr_handle() family for advanced options

code
title
usage

Bad Request

401
Unauthorized
No or invalid authentication


403
Forbidden
Known user can‚Äôt do that


404
Not Found
path arg doesn‚Äôt exist


502
Bad Gateway
Your api hits another api, got error


504
Gateway Timeout
Your api hits another api, timed out


500
Internal Server Error
Catch-all for other errors



See MDN HTTP response status codes for more options and further details

text:
plot endpoint

#* Plot out data from the iris dataset
#* @param spec If provided, filter the data to only this species (e.g. 'setosa')
#* @get /plot
#* @serializer png
function(spec) {
  myData <- iris
  title <- "All Species"

  # Filter if the species was specified
  if (!missing(spec)){
    title <- paste0("Only the '", spec, "' Species")
    myData <- subset(iris, Species == spec)
  }

  plot(myData$Sepal.Length, myData$Petal.Length,
       main=title, xlab="Sepal Length", ylab="Petal Length")
}

section: API keys with plumber: Process Keys
text:
API keys with plumber: Process Keys

#* Authorize user
#* @filter authorize_api_key
function(req) {
  api_key <- req$HTTP_AUTHORIZATION %||%            # Header
    req$session$api_key %||% req$cookies$api_key    # Cookies
  # Code to validate and process the API key.
  req$authorized <- TRUE # Or FALSE, set in auth section
  plumber::forward()
}


#* @preempt authorize_api_key if endpoint doesn‚Äôt use auth

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
API keys with plumber: Error

#* Error: Unauthorized
#* @filter stop_unauthorized
function(req) {
  if (req$authorized) {
    plumber::forward()
  }
  res$status <- 401L
  # TODO: do_the_log_thing() per plumber-errors.Rmd
  res$serializer <- plumber::serializer_json
  res$body <- list(
    error = "Unauthorized",
    message = "Obtain an API key at https://your_key_process.html"
  )
}


#* @preempt stop_unauthorized if endpoint doesn‚Äôt require auth

In addition to authorize_api_key if not used at all

deploy_api <- function(package, name, appName = name, ...) {
  api_dir <- withr::local_tempdir("api")
  file_path <- paste0(api_dir, "/entrypoint.R")
  entrypoint_text <- glue::glue(
    'library({package})',
    'plumber::plumb_api("{package}", "{name}")',
    .sep = "\n"
  )
  writeLines(entrypoint_text, file_path)
  rsconnect::deployAPI(api_dir, appName = appName, ...)
}
# Login to posit.cloud; click your name, then Account, then Tokens

section: What are the pieces of an HTTP request?

What are the pieces of an HTTP request?
HTTP request = URL + headers + method + body


Re-orient ourselves with the pieces of an HTTP request.
Focus on method.
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?

title: How can I do other things with APIs?
text:
What are HTTP request methods?

Paths are nouns
Methods are verbs

GET (fetch existing thing)
POST (push new thing)
DELETE (delete existing thing)
PATCH (change existing thing)
PUT (replace existing thing)
CONNECT, OPTIONS, HEAD, TRACE (very rare)




By convention for REST APIs

We‚Äôll dig into different API frameworks in a later chapter.

Path examples: candidates, calendar-dates, filings, electioneering (ads)
We‚Äôve been doing GET by default
CONNECT = ‚Äústart 2-way communication‚Äù (eg ask server to be a bridge)
OPTIONS should tell you method options
HEAD returns headers that you‚Äôd get with GET

Eg, use it to check if DL would be big.

TRACE returns the request as the final server received it, with header info about route.
Methods aren‚Äôt strict

API owner can do weird things.
GET or POST often used for ~everything

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
Authentication schemes overview

HTTP Basic Authentication: username + password sent with request
API Keys/Bearer Tokens: password-like thing sent with request

Dirty secret: This is what more complex schemes are, eventually
httr2::req_auth_bearer_token()
Sometimes: httr2::req_headers()

OAuth: Multi-step process to generate a key

Goal: Make the key as short-lived as possible
Not everyone implements the same way (ie often wrong)
httr2::req_oauth_*()

Other:

Cookies
Certificates

Access entire account

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
OAuth: Terminology

User: You, or someone using your code
Client: The thing asking for permission to act as the user

Your code, but also
A reusable thing that represents your code
Client ID: Codename
Client secret: Client ‚Äúpassword‚Äù, but often not very secret

Authorization server (auth): Thing granting permission (usually the API owner)

Often multiple servers (auth vs auth2 on next slide)

Resource server (API): Thing user is using (the API)
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How do I tell the API who I am?

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
The OAuth ‚Äúdance‚Äù

User to client: Hit this API for me!
Client (ID) to auth: Can I act as this user and do these things?
Auth to user: Is this ok?
User to auth: Yes
Auth to client‚Äôs home address: Use this to get a key
Client (ID + secret) to auth2: Turn this into a key (I‚Äôm really me!)
Auth2 to client: Here‚Äôs your key (and I‚Äôll log what it can do)
Client to API: Here‚Äôs my key
API to auth: Can this key do this?
Auth to API: (checks logged scopes) Yes!
API to client: Ok, here‚Äôs the info!

TODO: Image of OAuth dance
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
OAuth credential dangers

üü¢ Client id: Like knowing a package name.
üü° Client secret:

Can pretend to be your client, but user still needs to say ok
Can your client do anything special?

Installed (e.g.¬†Slack app)?
API usage limits?


üü° Authorization code: Unlikely to be an issue

Only sent to provided redirect_uri
Extremely short lived (often minutes or less)
crumbs: How can I interact with the web from R?
How do I tell the API who I am?

title: Web APIs with R Book Club
text:
OAuth credential dangers (cont)

üü° Refresh token: A longer-lived authorization code

Can be used to get a new access token
Usually revoked if you auth from scratch
Also need client secret to refresh

üü† Access token: The thing we‚Äôre protecting

Can do whatever it‚Äôs authorized to do
Usually easy to revoke

üî¥ Username + password: We don‚Äôt want to know these

title: How do computers communicate?
text:
Browsers and HTTP Requests
https://wapir.io/apis.html is an HTTP request:

https:// = ‚Äúuse HTTP(s) protocol‚Äù
URL: wapir.io/apis.html = URL
headers: Cookies (plus some info about your browser)
method: GET
body: Empty



Request = URL + headers + method + body
You (kinda) use APIs all the time!

title: How do computers communicate?
text:
HTTP API Frameworks: Historic

RPC = Remote Procedure Call

Endpoints = actions
XML-RPC & JSON-RPC popular early
Often just GET (GET /deleteItem/1234)

SOAP = Simple Objects Access Protocol (briefly huge, mostly dead)

Evolved from XML-RPC
Technically not limited to HTTP




RPCs are making a come back (we‚Äôll see in a couple slides)

title: How do computers communicate?
text:
HTTP API Frameworks: Modern

REST = REpresentational State Transfer

Most common by far
Stateless (call defines the object)
Technically endpoints = nouns
What we‚Äôll focus on in most of book

GraphQL = Graph Query Language

Body defines everything

JSON with wildcards telling server what to fill in

Basically GET + 1 endpoint
More details in ‚ÄúHow else can I communicate with APIs from R?‚Äù




REST APIs often called ‚ÄúRESTful‚Äù APIs.
GraphQL should be bigger than it is for data science

title: How do computers communicate?
text:
Other API Frameworks

websocket

ws:// or wss:// vs http:// or https://
2-way communication
{websocket} package

gRPC = Google RPC

Good for real-time, 2-way communication
Uses HTTP/2 (more socket-like)


Deeper dive coming in ‚ÄúHow else can I communicate with APIs from R?‚Äù!


Shiny is websocket between server (R) and ui (JS)
gRPC best for tightly coupled microservices





r4ds.io/wapir | Jon Harmon | wapir.io

title: Web APIs with R
text:

title: Web APIs with R
text:
Forward/Backward Design
Understanding by Design (Grant Wiggins and Jay McTighe, 1998)


Forward:

Plan lessons about material
Create assessment to measure learning
ID what learners know


Backward:

ID what learners need to know
Create assessment to measure learning
Plan lessons to help learners succeed at assessment





‚ÄúForward‚Äù is ‚Äúnormal‚Äù way of teaching.

Eg, teachers choosing a book to read then deciding what to put on the test.

‚ÄúLearner-centered‚Äù design.
‚ÄúWhat learners need to know‚Äù == learning objectives
To avoid: ‚ÄúTeaching the test.‚Äù

There‚Äôs still nuance to making sure you‚Äôre preparing students to answer any question within LOs.
